author: sky.cactus
content: This isn't a reasonable backstop when you are trying to create a credibly neutral trusted setup ceremony.

author: sky.cactus
content: "Don't worry, we trusted the trusted party at the time the trusted setup was run" isn't a compelling story to future users of the platform.

author: sky.cactus
content: In fact, I would argue that if pretty much anyone claims the sequencer refused to accept their commitment , we should assume the trusted setup is compromised.

author: sky.cactus
content: Of course, this is extremely susceptible to trolling, so really there should be a mechanism for proving that the sequencer is rejecting your commitments such as by sharing your commitment with others so *they* can submit it and witness the censorship themselves.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ideally, this would be fully automated with a gossip network, so if the sequencer says your commitment was invalid, you would then gossip it out to the network and everyone who received it would check it for validity and then attempt to submit themselves.  If they also witnessed censorship, they would propagate the commitment to their peers and flag the sequencer as corrupt from their point of view.

author: sky.cactus
content: This would allow us to have pretty high confidence that if the sequencer is censoring someone's commitment, then everyone running a client would be personally witness the censorship, rather than a single person who may be crying wolf.

author: sky.cactus
content: **TL;DR**: "Don't worry, the sequencer can be trusted to not lie." is **not** an acceptable component to a trusted setup ceremony.

<kevaundray> > <kevaundray>  What if I submit an invalid contribution to the sequencer, then submit a valid contribution to the rest of the network?

A sequencer censoring Alice's contribution and not Bob's does not make Bob's contribution invalid, so its possible to have a post ceremony where everyone who has been blacklisted is given a chance to contirbute via gated access to the ceremony (re @kzg_ceremony_bot: <Micah> Ideally, this would be fully automated with a gossip network, so if the sequencer says your commitment was invalid, you would then gossip it out to the network and everyone who received it would check it for validity and then attempt to submit themselves. author: sky.cactus
content: An honest participant will attempt to submit at the beginning of their turn.  If everything goes smoothly they'll commit quickly and be accepted quickly.  If the participant is a troll they will do nothing for all 3 minutes.  If the sequencer is malicious, the participant will submit at the start of the 3 minutes, get ignored by the sequencer (or receive a rejection) and they'll then gossip to their peers.  The peers will then submit on behalf of the censored user and also witness the censorship.  This repeats until either the 3 minutes are up or the sequencer accepts.

author: sky.cactus
content: If a peer witnesses censorship in this way, they would start sounding alarm bells and potentially stop following the sequencer.

author: sky.cactus
content: If half of the gossip network has personally witnessed the censorship (because they submitted on behalf of the censored participant and the slot timed out without acceptance) then we have a strong signal that the sequencer was corrupt/censoring.

author: sky.cactus
content: We don't need 100% of the network to witness the censorship, just enough that we can be confident that it wasn't just some troll *claiming* to be censored.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<dankrad> I believe there is a practical protocol now that resolves this problem:

1. If someone believes that they are being censored, they can shout out to the community.
2. Others can now verify this claim: They can set up a proxy through which the censored party can try to participate, and log the requests and responses. If they see a valid contribution being made but rejected by the sequencer, they know that the claim is true and can relay this to the community. 
3. Any claims of being censored after the ceremony has been run should be rejected.

author: frozenfire.eth
